title: Abstract for Unit 1 Lesson 15: Americans' Time on Task
body: This lesson introduces the "Time Use" Campaign by engaging students with an interactive graphic from The New York Times that visualizes data from the American Time Use Survey. Students will explore how different demographic groups spend their time, sparking curiosity about personal time allocation. A key objective is to develop skills in evaluating data-driven claims by analyzing the Pew Research Center's article on teens and social media usage. Students will use a K-L-W graphic organizer to document their knowledge and questions about the topic. The lesson culminates with students preparing to participate in the "Time Use Campaign" themselves, collecting their own time-use data over several days using provided digital tools, and learning to monitor data collection progress. They will also evaluate the Pew Research article based on data collection methods and claims made.

title: Unit 1 Lesson 15: Introduction to Time Use Campaign
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15, titled "Americans' Time on Task," aims to introduce students to the "Time Use" Campaign. The primary objective is for students to explore a multimedia graphic displaying data from the American Time Use Survey, thereby stimulating interest in personal time management. A crucial skill developed in this lesson is the ability to evaluate reports that present claims based on data. This is achieved by analyzing the Pew Research Center's article, "Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys." Students will utilize the K-L-W Graphic Organizer to structure their learning about time use and social media. The "Time Use Campaign" guidelines are also introduced to help students understand the campaign's objectives and guiding questions. This lesson bridges understanding survey data with personal data collection.

title: Materials for Unit 1 Lesson 15
body: The materials required for Unit 1 Lesson 15 include computers and data collection devices for students. Essential digital resources are the interactive multimedia graphic 'The New York Time's How Different Groups Spend Their Time,' accessible at [https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/interactive/2009/07/31/business/20080801-metrics-graphic.html](https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/interactive/2009/07/31/business/20080801-metrics-graphic.html), and the Pew Research Center article 'Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys,' available at [https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/04/24/teens-and-social-media-key-findings-from-pew-research-center-surveys/](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2023/04/24/teens-and-social-media-key-findings-from-pew-research-center-surveys/). Additionally, students will need the K-L-W Graphic Organizer, found in Teacher Resources, and the "Time Use Campaign" guidelines, located in the LMRs section.

title: Vocabulary: Evaluate
body: The term 'evaluate' is a key vocabulary word in Unit 1 Lesson 15. It means to think critically about something. In the context of this lesson, students are instructed to evaluate reports and articles that make claims based on data. This involves examining the evidence, methodology, and conclusions presented to determine the validity and reliability of the information. Critical evaluation is essential for understanding how data is used to support arguments and for developing statistical literacy.

title: Vocabulary: Claim
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 15, the term 'claim' is defined as a statement of something. When analyzing reports or articles that use data, it is important for students to identify the specific claims being made. A claim is essentially an assertion that something is true. Students will learn to distinguish between claims and the data or evidence used to support them, which is a fundamental aspect of critical thinking and data analysis.

title: Essential Concepts: Examining Analyses
body: A core concept in Unit 1 Lesson 15 is that learning to examine other analyses is an important part of statistical thinking. This means students are encouraged to critically review how data has been interpreted and presented by others. By dissecting reports, articles, and graphics that use statistical data, students develop a deeper understanding of the analytical process and learn to identify potential biases, limitations, or strengths in those analyses. This concept underpins the lesson's focus on evaluating data-driven claims.

title: Lesson Activity: Exploring the American Time Use Graphic
body: As part of Unit 1 Lesson 15, students begin by familiarizing themselves with the "Time-Use Campaign Guidelines." In pairs, they make predictions related to the campaign's overarching questions. The lesson then introduces the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) as a collector of American time-use data. Students access and explore the interactive multimedia graphic 'The New York Time's How Different Groups Spend Their Time' for 10 minutes. During this exploration, they are tasked with answering specific questions about the graphic's variables, its overall message, the data source, and interesting findings. These findings are then shared in pairs and subsequently with the whole class in a 'Whip Around' activity, encouraging collaborative learning and discussion.

title: Analyzing the American Time Use Graphic: Key Questions
body: During Unit 1 Lesson 15, students engage with the interactive graphic 'The New York Time's How Different Groups Spend Their Time' and are prompted to answer several key questions. These include identifying the variables represented (e.g., activities like sleeping, eating, socializing), explaining what the graphic communicates (e.g., time spent by different demographics on activities, percentage of people engaged in activities at specific times), and noting the origin of the data (surveys of Americans over 15 recalling a day in 2008). Students also identify and prepare to share interesting findings from the graphic, fostering critical observation and discussion.

title: Lesson Activity: Evaluating Teens and Social Media Article
body: Following the exploration of the American Time Use graphic in Unit 1 Lesson 15, students transition to analyzing the Pew Research Center's article, 'Teens and social media: Key findings from Pew Research Center surveys.' Using a K-L-W graphic organizer, students first record what they already 'Know' about the topic. After individually reading the article, they complete the 'Learn' column. Subsequently, they fill out the 'Want to Learn' column. The lesson emphasizes the importance of critically evaluating claims made in such articles. Students then work in teams to answer specific evaluation questions about the article's methodology, data collection, and the claims presented, preparing for a whole-class discussion.

title: Evaluating the Pew Research Article on Social Media
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 15, students evaluate the Pew Research Center's article on teens and social media by addressing targeted questions. They identify who was observed (1,316 U.S. teens aged 13-17 and their parents) and the variables (social media usage on platforms like YouTube, TikTok, etc., and its effects). They consider the statistical questions the study aimed to answer, such as daily time spent on specific platforms. They also determine who collected the data (Pew Research Center, conducted online by Ipsos) and how it was collected (online survey). Crucially, they identify the article's claims (e.g., majorities of teens use YouTube, TikTok, Instagram, Snapchat) and the statistics used to support these claims (e.g., usage percentages, perceptions of data control, parental concerns).

title: Introduction to the Time Use Participatory Sensing Campaign
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15 prepares students to engage in the 'Time Use Participatory Sensing' campaign. This involves collecting their own time-use data over a specified period. Students are guided on how to access and join the campaign through a digital platform. They are instructed to maintain a log of their activities throughout the day, potentially divided into intervals like 'before school,' 'after school,' and 'evening,' to account for all 1,440 minutes. This log will then be used to complete a survey. Students are required to keep this log for at least 5 days, including at least one weekend day, but no more than 10 days, ensuring a comprehensive dataset for their personal time use.

title: Homework and Data Collection for Time Use Campaign
body: The homework assignment for Unit 1 Lesson 15 involves students actively participating in the "Time Use Campaign" for the next five days. They will use their smart devices or a web browser to collect data on their personal time usage. This data collection is a crucial part of the campaign, allowing students to apply the concepts learned in the lesson to their own lives. The collected data will be tracked throughout the day, and students will submit a survey once their daily log is complete. This hands-on experience reinforces the importance of data collection and personal data analysis.

title: Data Collection Monitoring Tool
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 15, students and teachers are introduced to the IDS Campaign Monitoring Tool, accessible via [https://portal.thinkdataed.org](https://portal.thinkdataed.org). After signing in and navigating to 'Campaign Monitor,' users can view the 'User List' and sort it by 'Total' responses to identify who has collected the most data. Clicking on the pie chart provides insights into the number of active versus inactive users. The total number of submitted responses can also be viewed. The lesson encourages students to use this tool to reflect on their data collection progress and consider strategies to increase their participation. A further class data collection check is planned in the coming days.

title: Preparation for Next Steps: Lab 1F and Lesson 16
body: Unit 1 Lesson 15 concludes with instructions for upcoming activities. Students are directed to complete 'Lab 1F: A Diamond in the Rough' prior to the next lesson. Additionally, they are informed that they will conduct another data collection check with the whole class in a couple of days. This check will help students understand the distinction between private and shared data once their campaign data collection is complete. The lesson sets the stage for continued data analysis and understanding of data privacy through subsequent labs and lessons, specifically mentioning preparation for 'Lesson 16'.
